text.front:
Exploiting the Temporal Structure of MPEG Video
for the Reduction of Bandwidth Requirements
Marwan Krunz and Satish Tripathi
Institute for Advanced Computer Studies
Department of Computer Science
University of Maryland
College Park, MD 20742
Email: krunz@cs.umd.edu
Abstract
We propose a new bandwidth allocation scheme for VBR video tra c in ATM networks.
The scheme is tailored to MPEG-coded video sources that require stringent and deterministic
quality-of-service guarantees. By exploiting the temporal structure of MPEG sources, we show
that our scheme results in an e ective bandwidth which, in most cases, is less than the source
peak rate. The reduction in the bandwidth requirement is achieved without sacri cing any
perceived QoS. E cient procedures are provided for the computation of the e ective bandwidth
under heterogeneous MPEG sources. The e ective bandwidth strongly depends on the arrange-
ment of the multiplexed streams which is a measure of the degree of synchronization between the
GOP patterns of di erent streams. Assuming that all possible arrangements are equi-probable,
we derive an expression for the asymptotic tail distribution of the e ective bandwidth. From
the tail distribution, we compute several performance measures for the call blocking probability
when the allocation is made based on the e ective bandwidth. In the case of homogeneous
sources, we give a closed-form expression for the`best' arrangement that results in the`optimal'
e ective bandwidth. Numerical examples based on real MPEG traces are used to demonstrate
the advantages of our scheme.
Keywords: bandwidth allocation, MPEG, statistical multiplexing, CAC.
This research was partially supported by the NSF grant # CCR 9318933.
